facts: The Declaration of Independence was adopted on July 4, 1776, which is why the United States celebrates Independence Day on July 4.
The U.S. Constitution was written in 1787 and begins with the famous words, "We the People," to show that the government gets its power from citizens.
The Louisiana Purchase in 1803 nearly doubled the size of the United States when the U.S. bought a huge territory from France.
During the Civil War, President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation in 1863, declaring freedom for enslaved people in the Confederate states.
The 19th Amendment, ratified in 1920, gave women across the United States the right to vote.
In 1941, the attack on Pearl Harbor led the United States to enter World War II the next day.
The Civil Rights Act of 1964 made it illegal to discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin in many public places and jobs.
